column4: I'm trying to run "sudo chmod a=rxt D/ -R" on my thumb drive (D), but it reports operation not permitted?  Why not?
well for starters, the directory has to come last on the cmd line
IC, although I was able to run the command "sudo chmod u=rxt D/ -R" and it worked
Yes, but I wonder what it did?
sudo chmod a=rxt -R D/   - <--- what's that character?
just a typo, that wasn't in the real command
and when you say 'didn't work' what exactly did/didn't happen
what kind of filesystem is it?
it's fat32
also, "t" is the sticky bit. Only valid for directories & executables I believe. Not even sure if it has any meaning on a fat32 fs
let me try without that
what effect are you trying to achieve?
well, i'm just learning permission, so i'm playing around with making a live usb read only
whither this server a purpose or not is irrelivent, i'm just experimenting
you were right though, the t being applied to non-executables and non-directories appeared to be causing the error
then I would think you'd want chmod -R a=-w D/   i.e. turn off write on all files
thanks, you explained it well, i think i try some more things on my own
my pleasure....
a good secure installation shouldn't leave any tcp ports open unless it's serving something specific...
well that's what i have, because i can't find any tcp port to approach on my own system
that's a good thing!
decided i would just connect to a webserver on 80
